Award.AwardTitle: Enhancing the Potential of Lane College Undergraduates in STEM Programs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT HRD 0929257

Lane College is implementing a comprehensive initiative to enhance and strengthen STEM teaching and learning and to increase student enrollment and retention in STEM majors. The goal of ?Enhancing the Potential of Lane College Undergraduates in STEM Program? is to increase the number of STEM majors, and provide all science, technology, engineering and mathematics students with a challenging and enriching learning experience.

The project is being accomplished by implementing the following objectives: (1) build students? interest and confidence so they will pursue STEM degrees; (2) create programs that will enhance student retention and success in entry-level STEM courses; (3) provide targeted recruitment of underrepresented students to major in STEM disciplines; (4) create early undergraduate research experience in STEM by providing Summer internships for students; (5) provide stipends for faculty and students at collaborating universities and laboratories; (6) create an environment at Lane in which research is now accepted as an important part of a science student?s education; (7) provide professional development opportunities for faculty to ensure their participation and support for the project; and (8) improve STEM students? preparation for graduate or professional school by providing courses/ workshops for standardized exams.

Lane College is a coeducational, private historically black college that serves 2003 students, including 460 who are enrolled in STEM disciplines. Lane College offers the Bachelor of Science degree leading to majors in Biology, Chemistry, Mathematics, Physics and Computer Science. A major in Engineering is offered through a dual degree program with Tennessee State University in Nashville. Lane College is committed to increasing the number of minority students enrolling in and successfully completing baccalaureate programs that will prepare them to enter graduate and professional degree programs in STEM disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lane College is a small, Christian, Liberal Arts College in Jackson, TN. The College was founded in 1882 by a former slave, Bishop Isaac Lane, and is traditionally African-American. The College provides educational opportunities for those who may not otherwise have the opportunity to attend college; essentially the College has open enrollment. Many of the College’s students are under-prepared when they come to the College, especially in the STEM fields (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics). It was this lack of prior preparation of students, in addition to inadequate resources and an environment non-accepting of research, that initiated the attempt to get funding from the National Science Foundation (NSF) to help as follows:
The goal of this project was to enhance the potential of Lane College undergraduates in STEM programs. The specific objectives to reach this goal include:
a) Build students’ interest and confidence so they will pursue STEM courses;
b) Create programs that will enhance student retention and success in entry-level STEM courses;
c) Provide targeted recruitment of under-represented students to STEM disciplines;
d) Create early undergraduate research experiences in STEM by providing summer internships for students;
e) Provide stipends for faculty and students’ research at collaborating universities and laboratories;
f) Create an environment at Lane in which research is now accepted as an important part of a science student’s education;
g) Provide professional development opportunities for faculty to ensure their participation and support for the project;
h) Improve STEM students’ preparation for graduate or professional school by providing courses/workshops for standardized examinations.
Progress was made on objectives a), b), c), d), f), g), and h) using several different approaches; progress was not made on objective e).
To begin, funds received from NSF were initially used to finance the remodeling of one of the buildings on campus now also called the STEM Center. Housed in the STEM Center are a computer lab with approximately 24 computers, several offices of STEM faculty, and two classrooms. It is in the STEM Center that students come to be individually tutored. All STEM faculty are required to spend weekly at least three hours in the STEM Center where they are available to tutor students as needed. Students may also access the computers. The STEM Center is typically open 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. Funding was also used to acquire specialized instrumentation and equipment used to implement undergraduate and highschool research, and also to enhance effective teaching in the classroom, especially in the areas of biology and chemistry.
Two programs of the project utilized highschool students specifically and approached learning using the traditional classroom models where students move from classroom to classroom, or lab to lab. Students were exposed to all STEM areas represented at the College, including labs. Students also participated in English classes, and interacted with a counselor during a study block daily, where almost daily students were given presentations by visiting successful scientists, business men/women, and entrepreneurs.
Other activities undertaken included Student Research (Biology, Chemistry, and Computer Science), Individual Tutoring, and Student Meeting Participation. Additional activities undertaken to improve student learning and retention include Changes in Curriculum, involvement in STEM Center Operations, and Professional Development. Changes in the curriculum have been implemented to update the programs and help make students more competitive and understanding of concepts. Another way faculty helped was by involvement in the STEM Center Operations thru individual student tutoring. Some of the faculty participated in Professional Development through research and publication, and/or the attendance of conferences and workshops. The conferences/workshops helped keep the faculty current in their field and the students benefit from this.
Other positive interactions resulting from this project include Networking with Area High Schools and Campus Offices. In addition, local churches were notified, and the Lane College radio made announcements to the local community, regarding undergraduate and high school research, and advances made with the grant. These partnerships were also utilized in the recruitment of students for the STEM fields at the College.
The Lane College HBCU-UP project formed additional collaborations with other departments and units on campus including the English Department, the Office of Career Planning and Placement, the Office of Student Support Services, the Office of the Registrar, and the Office of Admissions. Each collaboration was unique in its own way, but all were for the betterment of success of students in the STEM disciplines.
As stated previously, we hope it is apparent that during the course of the project, progress was made on objectives a), b), c), d), f), g), and h) using several different approaches. However, satisfactory progress was not made on objective e). Although negotiations with other colleges and universities were pursued through the closing of the grant, satisfactory terms were never mutually agreeable.
